this has slightly bugged me, since most evolutionists don't understand why men have nipples. its quite simple, but it requres a bit of thinking outside the box:
 
 men have nipples because the laws of nature called for economized genetic code. think for a minute: if you have a perfectly good non asexual creature, do you really want to let that creature die out when you start another creature from scratch? i wouldnt. it would make no sense- thats why the sexual organs of men and women are basically inverted copies of each other- testicles to ovaries, penis to vagina, etc. the ONLY exception- and possibly not an exception, if we ever learn more about it- is the clitoris. small variations are what produce more or less attractive variations: for example, if a male human has man-tits, he's less attractive and therefore less likely to breed. if somebody has huge elephant-like ears, they won't breed unless there is a socially acceptable reason for them to (look at prince charles). however, if the good things outweigh the bad- if the guy with man-tits is a marathon runner who can go two or three times as long as anyone else in the world- then maybe, just maybe, they will be genetically viable.

Utter nonsense! The reason males have nipples is because 
 an embryo starts out female, it isn't until about 2 months that the y chromosome turns on testosterone production and the fetus starts to develope male characteristics, but by this time breast tissue, milk ducts and nipples have already formed. Now, while nipples have no major function in males, they are not dterimental either, so there are no natural selction pressures that would cause males to lose them. Questions like these are pretty easily answered by biology if you bother to do the research.

 i'm not upset, just mildly amused. you're acting like a christian- refusing to admit you could *possibly* be wrong. how preposterous that would be! i can see that you're smarter than that. so why do you insist on flaming on something so stupid? the reason men *still* have nipples is perfectly reasonable given the data you've forwarded- the reason i gave is why they were ever there in the first place: because mammals in general, and primates specifically, have nearly identical characteristics in males and females, because they're constructed of the same basic genetic code. if you want to look at something thats the opposite of that, look at the deep sea angler fish: the males hatch and swim around, find a female, and then become little more than permanently attached symbiotic testicles. this would be plausible if humans were like frogs- eg, if they could change sex while in the womb- but as far as anyone knows, we can't. the closest we come is the testicles creating more or less male sperm depending on the temature. even though the male and female embryos may seem alike, when it comes right down to it, they ARE different, in {at least} one important way: chromosomes.
 
 as for my logic- and please stop and think about it before you try to turn this into a big dick-measuring contest again- i draw these paralells: penis(the shaft)=vagina, a combination of the head and glans=the clitoris and the lips, the scrotum, testes, and the tract connecting the testes to the penis = uterus, ovaries, and fallopian tubes, respectively. since these things all have similar functions, it seems plausible that maybe- just possibly- the organs could be based on the same code.

 Buddy, he just explained basic human development. it's classic textbook.
 
 
The subject of male nipples is a sensitive, and maybe confusing, topic to many. Those who wish to invalidate evolutionary theory might pose the question, "Was man descended from woman?" The answer, of course, is no. Both men and women have nipples because in early stages of fetal development, an unborn child is effectively sexless. Nipples are present in both males and females; it is only in a later stage of fetal development that testosterone causes sex differentiation in a fetus. All mammals, male and female, have mammary glands. Male nipples are vestigial; they may perform a small role in sexual stimulation and a small number of men have been able to lactate. However, they are not fully functional and, because cancer can grow in male or female breast tissue, the tissue can be dangerous. 
 
 
 http://www.livescience.com/animalworld/top10_vestigial_organs-2.html

The labia are not turned inside out to form the scrotum, since the labia aren't inverted in the first place. And the penis certainly isn't a vagina turned inside out - unless maybe your penis is below your scrotum.
